reviewText: If you have read the reviews, you've noticed much difference of opinion.  Good reason for it - it has some quality parts, some unnecessary garbage.  If you are the type to see past the garbage, the rest is good!  My wife and I mostly 'put up with' the first half or so, then enjoyed most of the rest.  It does have enough profanity and 'sleazy' characters to offend.  Yes, life does have such people in real life, so it isn't unreal, but some, including myself, don't enjoy spending money for the 'joy' of watching such real life behavior.  The last part of the movie does bring together many loose ends created in the first part, showing some good choices - keep on despite trouble, look for real value rather than shallow temporary gain, etc.  My understanding is that Thomas Kinkade has a definite commitment to spiritual values - it is really not shown in this movie.  It shows moral values, but not clearly based in spiritual (Christian) ones.  The church in the movie has some solid role models along with characters that make church goin' people look silly.Over all, I do not plan to watch it again.  I do hope to watch the special feature with Thomas Kinkade sharing some commentary.  You will have to judge whether to take the risk of view/buying it yourself.

reviewText: "Thomas Kinkade's Christmas Cottage" reminded me of what is best and worst of Kinkade's prodigious output of 'family-friendly' art; it is warm, optimistic, and glowing...but it is also unrealistic, contrived, and calculated to 'sell'. The film appears to have ambitions of becoming a modern "It's a Wonderful Life", but sorely lacks Frank Capra's gift for truly understanding people. In a world where everyone is basically 'nice', selfless acts are not miraculous, but expected, and this robs "Christmas Cottage" of any real emotional energy. What you wind up with is a marshmallow confection; sweet, but not particularly filling.Set in Placerville, California in the late 1970s, and based on Kinkade's experiences as an art student returning home for the holidays, the film introduces the young artist (well-played by Jared Padalecki), then attempts to ingratiate us with the sweet-natured 'characters' of the town, but most come across as caricatures, including Kinkade's overly supportive mother (Marcia Gay Harden), a saint who tries to solve everyone's problems as the family house crumbles into disrepair around her. Fortunately, Kinkade's neighbor and artist/mentor Glen Wesman (in real life, Glen Wessels...why his name was changed for the film is not explained), as portrayed by Peter O'Toole, is a welcome exception, blunt, introspective, and refreshingly candid.To earn money to keep his mother from losing their home, Kinkade accepts a commission to paint an outdoor Christmas mural celebrating the town, and the story unfolds as the mural emerges, as the local church rehearses an unintentionally funny Christmas pageant, two neighbors compete for the most outdoor decorations for the holidays, Kinkade's ne'er-do-well father (Richard Burgi) admits his own shortcomings, and Wesman drifts in and out of lucidity. The various subplots, while diverting, have little more depth than a TV-movie, and lack dramatic power.When nearly everything ends disasterously, a contrived "Wonderful Life" moment appears, meant to bring tears of joy, but which left me unmoved. The loose ends are tied up neatly, and Kinkade goes on to earn over $50 million selling 'feel-good' landscapes.The Special Features are a mixed bag, offering an in-film Commentary by Thomas Kinkade and director Michael Campus, Deleted Scenes (which are actually better than some left in!), a somewhat self-congratulatory feature on how the film came about, cast reflections on their own favorite Christmas, and a bizarre vignette of a biker 'extra' (portrayed by Kinkade, himself) getting himself fired from the film.Production-wise, the film isn't bad, but the script lacks a willingness to take risks, and the end result is no classic. If you love Kinkade's art (as millions do), you will probably enjoy the film; if, however, you are looking for true emotional satisfaction, stick with "It's a Wonderful Life".
summary: A Bland Christmas Story in Pastel Hues...

reviewText: I thought the movie was 'ok' for once a year holiday viewing.  It has a number of fine actors (with Peter O'Toole standing out as always) as the elder painter suffering from Parkinson's Disease like symtoms.  I think the film needed a script which matched the calibre of the actors they got.  The 'bad' language that some viewers commented on, sorry, did not bother me... kids hear far worse in their homes, schools (and in churches at times).  The picture struck a pretty good balance with being heartwarming, Christmas-y and showing realistic small town life (which can be far from 'family-friendly' believe me).  Still the plot (except for that part involving Mr. O'Toole) seemed predictable.  I'd watch it once a year, as part of my family's lineup (and plan to purchase it).  The interview with Kinkade is interesting as he speaks about what it was like to grow up in a family w/o a father and a working mother who supported his family.
summary: Good for once a year holiday viewing
Title: N/A

reviewText: Based on a true story about the artist Thomas Kinkade it tells us about one Christmas he had at home while attending college. An interesting look into the artist's life, it gives some insight into his family life and how he developed his painting style. As a fan of his art I wanted to see this movie and find out more about him. It is capably done with good acting, scenery, sets, music, and directing. The cast has several well known actors including Peter O'Toole. Each of them donates a key piece to the movies recognition of self.When Kinkade goes home for Christmas he finds that his mother is about to lose the cottage that he and his brother grew up in. The two brothers both look for work to pay the bills. As they try to scrape together the money they begin to really see a side to their mother they never knew. Although she has been hit with many challenges she strives to take care of her two sons and to help her town in any way that she can. Unfortunately for her about anything that can go wrong, goes wrong. We find out she has been doing what she can since she was laid off. Fortunately the town pitches in to fix up her home so that she may sell it instead of lose it.CA Luster

reviewText: This was a lovely Christmas story loosely based on the life of Thomas Kinkade.  What I enjoyed most was the relationship between Thomas and his mentor, Glen.  Peter O'Toole does a tremendous job portraying the famous artist and I became extremely fond of him in this movie. Their relationship is very inspiring.  For me, the story was very real to life--portraying life struggles that can be seen on just about every corner.  Family loyalty and love (between Thomas and is mother and brother) and community spirit were all prominently shown here and acted as a reminder of what can "be". If you are a fan of the late artist's wonderful paintings, you won't want to miss this touching story about how Kinkade's paintings came to life..."paint the light, Thomas!"

reviewText: Some weirdos are getting on here saying this is not a family movie due to vulgarity and sensuality. I don't think they saw the same movie I saw. reviewText: My wife loves Thomas Kinkade; and I guess I do too.  Also, we're both very Christmasy people.  CHRISTMAS COTTAGE seemed to be right up our alley.  But this movie which should have been one of the best family Christmas films ever is laced with very adult themes and crude material.  There is a fair amount of unnecessary profanity as well as sexual themes in this film.Yes, there is some heartwarming and sentimental feeling in COTTAGE, as well as an outstanding performance by Peter O'Toole.  But how much garbage should a viewer have to wade through to get to the good stuff?  It just isn't worth it.  There are plenty of wonderful Christmas movies out there.  CHRISTMAS COTTAGE does not earn a place among them.

reviewText: For those who purchase this Christmas movie, I HIGHLY recommend viewing the 20-minute or so Special Feature in which the actual Thomas Kinkade comments on the story, his relationship with Glen Wessells, and his art career. It's a fascinating feature and might be more wisely viewed before watching the movie than after the final credits fade.I especially enjoyed the last 30 minutes or so when the movie finally "settled" into what I consider the "meatier" part of the plot. At that point the quality of the movie shifted from a mediocre made-for-TV production -- although,in fact, it was not made-for-TV. During that final half hour, the quality of the story and the acting changed to a much richer depiction of the relationship of young, budding artist Kinkade and the source of his inspiration from the talented real-life painter Glen Wessels (played convincingly by Peter O'Toole), whose physical and mental faculties were failing significantly as Kinkade's were evolving. The last third of the film likewise portrayed much more convincingly that Kinkade's family and home town residents were witnessing the blossoming of a very talented young man's painting career.If the first hour had been as well done as the last 30 minutes, I'd have rated the movie 4 stars. Unfortunately the first hour was lackluster. At one point it seemed that the movie would focus on Thomas Kinkade. Then it seemed to focus on the possible foreclosure of the Kinkade cottage and the mother's and sons' struggles to keep the family's home from the clutches of the mortgage company. There were a couple of other meager attempts to give the story coherence, but those didn't pan out either.Jared Padalecki's performance was very good throughout the film, and O'Toole's went from very good to masterful toward the very end. The rest of the acting by the cast was mediocre, which is surprising considering Marcia Gay Harden had a major role.Due to some lame attempts at crude and suggestive humor, I'd recommend this for adults and older teens.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I actually purchased it to watch with friends for the cheese factor (and because Chris Elliott is in it), and we were not disappointed: this was the most awful movie I have ever seen.  Every line was painfully overwritten and unnatural, the plot was trite and predictable, and I cannot fathom a person having a genuine emotional respose to it.The whole thing was so poorly done it nearly moved me to tears...from laughter!There's a part near the end where Jared Padalecki was giving a heartfelt speech to Peter O'Toole and O'Toole was staring at him like there were zombies behind him about to rip his head off.  Why they thought that take was OK to commit to film, I'll never know.I gave it two stars rather than the one that it earned just because it made me laugh.  If you get humor and irony, get a cheap copy of this to show at your next party.  If you love it for real...I'm sorry.

reviewText: As I watched this film I had to keep in mind that I was watching events based on "Thomas Kindade's" life. Porn magazines, bickering at the "Christmas" play, bar scenes, to much cleavage, a not so wholesome minister, and a busybody neighbor are not the sort of things that belong in "Christmas" movies. And they are certainly not the sort of things I enjoy or even want in a "Christmas" film. If it hadn't been for "Peter O'Toole" I would have rated this movie one star. I found myself trying to watch this film, as I must have played it over and over, without truly getting into it. This movie is best used as a filler when you're not watching tv and you just want something to listen to. Though you still want something related to Christmas, somehow, but you don't want to put on the good stuff because you want to watch that. As I had written on a reply to a review, if I had read some of the reviews first, I may not have bought this. If you want to buy this, find a good used copy or try to get it through your local library first. And in either case, don't pay more than $5.00-$5.50 for it. That way you won't feel as if you put out a bit to much for a not so good movie.

reviewText: I bought this movie for two reason's. I'm a "big" Jared Padalecki fan and I "love" Christmas. From the acting right down to the music, I LOVE everything about this film. Some reviewer's have called it "sappy". Well of course its sappy, its a Christmas movie!!! Its about love, loyalty, laughter and life. It makes me cry everytime I watch it, but its not one of those sad, terrible cries. Its one of those sad but still happy and filled with joy for life cries. In fact, last week I was having a bad day and I decided to put the movie in the machine and watched it again. At first I felt kinda silly watching a Christmas movie in the middle of April but I'm so glad I did because it made me feel awesome for the rest of the week. If you love Christmas and any of the actor's in this movie, then do yourself a favor and get it. You won't be sorry you did. Its now a permanent part of my Christmas collection.

reviewText: We are great fans of Thomas Kinkade's art, and his Christian testimony. In purchasing this movie we were hopeful of a warm, family movie. We liked the actors and found in the end it had some positive things...family and friends supporting and encouraging one another. However, we felt there were things that would keep us from showing it to children  or recommending it to others. Some low and bulging necklines, a father encouraging immorality in his sons by magazines, comments, and lifestyle; an openly immoral young woman playing Mary in the Christmas program. It is true that there are all kinds of people in life, and that there is good in everyone. Our expeience is that it is actually the man that is relating properly to his Lord that has the strength of character to find the right course in life and impact others for good. This testimony, which we believe is true of Mr. Kinkade's life, is not made evident in this movie.

reviewText: Hands down, this is one of the best movies I've ever seen in my life. Some reviewers have been critical of the fact that it appears to be a "warm fuzzy movie for the family" and yet, it probably is not appropriate for children. There is some foul language (although not out of hand), and there are depictions of smoking, drinking, and cleavage. However, it's all done in the context of illustrating the characters and never feels ugly or obscene. It is not, by any stretch, an obnoxious film as some reviewers seem to have suggested,  and it an amazing and "warm fuzzy film" that has so many special moments I can't count them. One feels "opened up" after watching it. However, if one if very religious, skip this offering; there are better for you.However, if seen simply as a movie without critical regard for counting expletives (which I honestly didn't even notice--am I just deaf, or so ingrained in the culture that I don't even hear it?), this is a powerful, poignant and moving experience which won't leave dry eyes. The music, the profound wisdom about life, art and humanity, and the many many touching scenes put this film in the category of the greats. I think I could watch this film 10 times and still get something out of it. Peter O'Toole is magnificent, and he along with the lady costar who plays the mom have some amazing special moments together--and the music is breathtaking and perfect. There are some scenes with an artist painting, that are so moving and profound.Here are some of the amazing themes/issues covered:* Never Give up in the face of adversity* Loving those around you always returns manyfold to you* Life is about expression, love, connection, and honesty* Always give your finest, your very very best in everything you do, even if you don't think those around you "deserve it."* Each of us has something amazing, powerful, and special to give* Love triumphs over all* Family's should stick together* Friendship can be one of the most beautiful gifts/experiences life has to offer* Honor our elders--they have immense wisdom, beauty, and gifts to bring* You are never too old to accomplish anything your heart desiresAnother powerful aspect of this film is it is based on the real life of the painter Thomas Kinkade. So not only are you taken on an inspiring cinematic journey into the depths of the meaning of life, love, family, and friendship, but one is also learning about the amazing and profound life of the painter. It's a fantastic movie in every regard, a masterpiece, a triumph of the human spirit. It should be in your library.If you liked Steele Magnolias, you will love this film. Another warm/fuzzy film is also The Ultimate Gift--don't miss it either.
summary: Phenomenal, Moving, Powerful, Profound...Amazing Film. Period.

reviewText: I ordered the Christmas Cottage DVD and we watched it on Thanksgiving with the family.  I am very disappointed and feel it should have been rated PG-13 as a lot of the content was embarrassing to watch with children.  The nativity was mocked and made fun of, the young women with so much breast showing was deplorable and embarrassing to watch with the men in our family, in addition to the sexual innuendos, excessive cursing...  I cannot believe that such a DVD was even made by Thomas Kinkade.  My eyes have been opened as to what he is really like.  I am not talking about him as a person, but for him to allow sexual innuendos, mockery of the real meaning of Christmas and excessive cursing was so unnecessary and ruined the nice movie.  I am trying to get rid of it.  I am going to warn every one of my Christian friends that this movie is not what it appears to be.  True believers, beware!!
summary: Wish I could give it NO stars...

reviewText: This is a movie which is sure to divide people. It is based on the early life of Thomas Kinkade, "the painter of light". It is a story of the sources of his inspiration:his mentor,and how the difficulties faced by his mother provided a motivation through which he began to find himself.Its weakness is that it isn't sure of its own purpose.It is certainly not a biography or a christmas movie in the ordinary sense and its comedic moments often miss the mark.In many ways it is like a Kinkade picture: a little sugary and sentimental yet with a warmth and humanity that can touch our hopes for a world where we all have a place and where everything comes out alright in the end However,it it isn't grounded in the reality of the world as we know it. The script is very uneven,occasionally very hammy,yet produces some fine moments. Peter o' Toole's performance as Tom's mentor, rapidly approaching dotage and a loss of his powers is a fine one and justifies a viewing.I also enjoyed the background music.Not for anyone who shrinks from sentimentality,but overall I'm glad I watched it.Loading...Item being reviewedThomas Kinkade's Christmas Cottage [DVD] [2006]
summary: A movie like a Kincade picture

reviewText: I read a lot of reviews of this film and not many of them were kind. There was a lot of talk that the people weren't represented properly and the town was made a joke. If this were the case and people were so offended on behalf of the Kinkade family... why is it that Thomas Kinkade himself helped make the movie happen? He was intimately involved in its creation process.Because of the reviews, I got this on netflix first and then turned around and bought it on here upon watching it. It was charming and heartwarming. I laughed, I cried, and enjoyed it quite a lot. The cast was amazing. Jared Padalecki is fantastic in everything he does, as is Peter O'Toole and Marcia Gay Harden. This is worth a watch and especially a great addition to a Christmas movie collection. The chemistry between Padalecki and O'Toole is fantastic.

reviewText: I was a little surprised I like this film. My threshold for sappy Christmas feel good dramas is low, but I confess I enjoyed seeing Jared Padelecki in something outside of Supernatural. While the story is a wee bit predictable, and some of the themes a bit trite: The glories of small town living vs. the life of the city, and wholesome smalltown girl vs. big city girl, I confess I enjoyed it .This *IS* a Christmas movie, so expect sappy sentimentality. I particularly felt the parents were quite stereotypical: Hardworking, devoted, (at times almost unrealistically so) martyr-like single mom vs. father who never grew up. But I thought it was a cute nonetheless. The message at the end was uplifting and simple.While the movie wasn't rocket science, it was good to watch once, and my family liked it.

reviewText: This movie was a gift to my sister.  She viewed the coming attractions of The Christmas Cottage while enjoying another movie.  We can all appreciate Thomas Kinkade and his gift, bringing out the light in his paintings.  This was a true story of the painter and the people who influenced his life and encouraged him to pursue the gift of painting.  Through family financial struggles and a split homelife, Thomas succeeded to become a renowned and much appreciated painter.  Lifes touching lifes and the true value of love and friendship made this an outstanding motion picture.  He reached out to others in his hometown and found value in all the friends and towns people.  He brought the outstanding quality of love and unity and unselfishly made a difference in the lives of others.  You must see this picture yourself and maybe your life experience will have greater meaning and direction.  A truely beautiful movie.

reviewText: I have to admit I watched this solely on the prior reviews here with both 1 and 5 ratings. This film ended up being such a colossal bin of sap and schmaltz though, I felt compelled to write about it.The most noticeable critique I read prior was the foul language - there wasn't any (unless damn and hell are considered R ratings to some people now). The "vulgarity" and "sensuality" is so tame that it did not even deserve to be mentioned. This film was about a painter's early inspiration that coincides with the holiday season 1977 in Placerville, CA - so I am not sure what the fuss was about in warning the younger family about seeing this; they would be bored anyway.The acting was wholeheartedly forced and schmaltzy, and the sole redeeming performance of Mr. O'Toole cannot save the film, admittedly I love hearing his voice orate philosophy in any film. Marcia Gay Harden tries, but they asked her to do so many corny faces and lines you could tell she was in pain. Richard Moll acted like he just came off the Night Court set, as did Ed Asner's few minutes on screen from his last couple holiday films, as did Chris Elliot stumbling from the Groundhog Day set. I guess in that right they picked all holiday actors, but it still fell short of believable. It has the slight feel of a Lifetime movie, but with a higher budget; the cars and sets appeared to be correct and thorough for the era.The special features are for the Kincade fans, as there are four docus/set pieces that give plenty of insight about Kincade and the production process. The sound issues (written here) were non existent as both the 5.1 and 2.0 are included for you, so I would venture to guess people had bad system setups. The PG rating is actually correct, but I do not think this will rank up there as one of those that the young ones will watch anyway.

reviewText: I read unflattering reviews of this movie, and I couldn't disagree more.  Thomas Kinkade really does paint "light" like no one I've ever seen, and it was wonderful to see how he got to the place he is as an artist.  His early life was portrayed beautifully, and it's another "triumph out of tragedy" story.  Poverty in early life never has to be the last word!

reviewText: (SPOILERS)I am not interested in religions at all so the whole church/religious community aspects...rubbed me the wrong way. However, I did not know that was in the film, I bought it on a whim because I like some of the actors. It is based on a true story about a young artist Thomas, goes to his small town of Placervillie to paint a mural for x-mas. Along the way we find out his mother is going to lose her home (his childhood home) because she's too giving AND has lost her job. So the gist of the story is about a community coming together to help each other out and love in general.But yeah, I didn't like the whole religous aspect of the film (because I believe you can have love and hope without faith/religon) but hey, if that's your thing, go for it. It was a segmented film in which you'd be looking at one part of the story, go to another, go back to the first part, jump over here. It was important for the story telling because it focused on the community of Placervillie itself. They showed a variety of side characters, giving glimpses into their heart ache and joy. Simple, it is an alright Christmas film.Now it is a cute film. It was created by a company that wants to create only family friendly (with messages) entertainment and I believe they did suceed in the fact that there is no vulgarity/sexuality/etc. like they intended. So yes, good film to sit the youngest ones down with. But if you prefer more action, more laughs, more in general than this watered down type of movie, skip it.

reviewText: I mainly watched this movie for the cast.  They all lived up to their abilities!  The movie showed much love and caring.  I'll admit there were a few "people" who made you want to turn away, but this was about a small town and the people who lived there.  Doesn't every town have those people????  This movie made you laugh and cry.  It makes you realize that you need to live up to your potential.  Don't forget where you came from and that God is always there to get you through.  Giving is the most powerful gift of all!
summary: Reminder of how families stay together

reviewText: This movie would be stirring and wonderful even if it weren't a true story, mostly due to the two male leads. Jared Padalecki plays the young Thomas Kinkade before he had found his niche in the painting world and when he was beset with family problems. His ability to emote and show a wide range of emotions is unsurpassed. And the late, great, internationally renowned Peter O'Toole plays his mentor with such attention to the slightest detail that it is almost painful. This is a movie not to be missed.
